summary.overview: The Meal Finder application allows users to search for meals by keywords, view detailed information about specific meals, and fetch random meals. The application dynamically updates the UI based on user interactions and API responses.
summary.predefined_options: Default behavior includes fetching and displaying a random meal when the page loads or when the 'Random' button is clicked.

requirements.description: When the user types a keyword into the search input field and clicks the search button, the system must fetch meals matching the keyword from the API and display them in the meals container. If no results are found, the system must display a message indicating no results were found.

When the user clicks the 'Random' button, the system must fetch a random meal from the API and display its details in the single meal container. The meals container and result heading must be cleared.

When the user clicks on a meal element in the meals container, the system must fetch detailed information about the selected meal using its ID and display the details in the single meal container. The page must scroll smoothly to the single meal container.
When the page loads, the system must automatically fetch and display a random meal in the single meal container.
When the user submits the search form with an empty input field, the system must fetch and display a random meal in the single meal container.
The system must dynamically update the result heading to display the search term or relevant messages (e.g., 'Search results for "term"' or 'No results found. Try another keyword!').

The system must dynamically update the meals container to display a list of meals fetched from the API, including meal images and names. Each meal element must include a clickable area to fetch detailed information.
The system must dynamically update the single meal container to display detailed information about a meal, including its name, image, category, area, ingredients, and instructions.

If the API call fails during any operation (search, random meal fetch, or meal details fetch), the system must display an error message in the relevant container (result heading or single meal container).
The system must clear the search input field after the user submits the search form.
